item.title: AG Eric Holder to resign
item.description: An almost certainly bruising confirmation battle for his successor will follow.
item.media:text: An almost certainly bruising confirmation battle for his successor will follow.

item.title: U.S. has no evidence of Islamic State plot against subways: sources
item.description: WASHINGTON (Reuters) - The United States has no evidence to back up an Iraqi claim that Islamic State forces were plotting to attack U.S. subway systems, two senior U.S. government security officials told Reuters on Thursday. In the past, the United States had received threats that various militant groups were targeting such transportation systems but there is no recent information about an imminent plan by Islamic State, one official said, speaking on the condition of anonymity. ...
item.media:text: WASHINGTON (Reuters) - The United States has no evidence to back up an Iraqi claim that Islamic State forces were plotting to attack U.S. subway systems, two senior U.S. government security officials told Reuters on Thursday. In the past, the United States had received threats that various militant groups were targeting such transportation systems but there is no recent information about an imminent plan by Islamic State, one official said, speaking on the condition of anonymity. ...

item.title: Cruise ship assists in rescuing hundreds off coast of Cyprus
item.description: LIMASSOL, Cyprus (AP) — A cruise ship picked up hundreds of people, apparently refugees who fled Syria, who were stranded aboard a small boat off Cyprus on Thursday, officials said.
item.media:text: LIMASSOL, Cyprus (AP) — A cruise ship picked up hundreds of people, apparently refugees who fled Syria, who were stranded aboard a small boat off Cyprus on Thursday, officials said.

item.title: Donald Verrilli, Kamala Harris top list to replace Attorney General Eric Holder
item.description: Getting a new attorney general confirmed by the Senate, which could possibly be controlled by the Republicans come January, will be challenging for President Obama, deep in the second term of his presidency.
item.media:text: Getting a new attorney general confirmed by the Senate, which could possibly be controlled by the Republicans come January, will be challenging for President Obama, deep in the second term of his presidency.

item.title: U.S. Attorney General Holder to step down after contentious term
item.description: By Julia Edwards WASHINGTON (Reuters) - Eric Holder, the first black U.S. attorney general and one of President Barack Obama's closest allies, will announce on Thursday he is stepping down after a contentious term marked by advances in civil rights and frequent battles with Republicans in Congress. Holder will remain in office until a successor is nominated and confirmed, the Justice Department said. Obama is scheduled to join him for the announcement at the White House at 4:30 p.m. ET (2030 GMT). ...
item.media:text: By Julia Edwards WASHINGTON (Reuters) - Eric Holder, the first black U.S. attorney general and one of President Barack Obama's closest allies, will announce on Thursday he is stepping down after a contentious term marked by advances in civil rights and frequent battles with Republicans in Congress. Holder will remain in office until a successor is nominated and confirmed, the Justice Department said. Obama is scheduled to join him for the announcement at the White House at 4:30 p.m. ET (2030 GMT). ...

item.title: Police chief issues apology over slain black teen in Missouri
item.description: By Carey Gillam (Reuters) - After weeks of heavy criticism and calls for his ouster, the police chief of Ferguson, Missouri, issued a video apology on Thursday to the parents of Michael Brown, the black teenager shot to death by a white police officer last month. "I want to say this to the Brown family. No one who has not experienced the loss of a child can understand what you are feeling," Chief Tom Jackson said in the video. "I am truly sorry for the loss of your son. ...
item.media:text: By Carey Gillam (Reuters) - After weeks of heavy criticism and calls for his ouster, the police chief of Ferguson, Missouri, issued a video apology on Thursday to the parents of Michael Brown, the black teenager shot to death by a white police officer last month. "I want to say this to the Brown family. No one who has not experienced the loss of a child can understand what you are feeling," Chief Tom Jackson said in the video. "I am truly sorry for the loss of your son. ...

item.title: University in Washington state given all-clear after bomb threat
item.description: SEATTLE (Reuters) - Police gave the all-clear on Thursday following a bomb threat that forced the evacuation of Gonzaga University in Spokane, Washington, emergency officials said. Campus police assisted by a bomb-sniffing dog and officers from the Spokane Police Department swept every building on the campus after receiving an early morning bomb threat by telephone, officials said. "There wasn't anything to substantiate this," said Officer Teresa Fuller, a spokeswoman for the Spokane Police Department. "It wasn't a credible threat." All academic buildings were evacuated about 8:10 a.m. ...

item.title: Congress channels leftover Afghan war funds to fight Ebola
item.description: WASHINGTON (AP) — Top lawmakers in Congress have approved the use of leftover Afghanistan war money to fight Ebola in West Africa.
item.media:text: WASHINGTON (AP) — Top lawmakers in Congress have approved the use of leftover Afghanistan war money to fight Ebola in West Africa.

item.title: UVa. student still missing after suspect captured in Texas
item.description: GALVESTON, Texas (AP) — A man charged with abducting a missing University of Virginia sophomore has been captured in Texas and is awaiting extradition — but there is still no sign of the student, authorities said.
item.media:text: GALVESTON, Texas (AP) — A man charged with abducting a missing University of Virginia sophomore has been captured in Texas and is awaiting extradition — but there is still no sign of the student, authorities said.

item.title: Iraq's leader: Plot uncovered for imminent attack on US, Paris subways
item.description: NEW YORK (AP) — Iraq's prime minister said Thursday that captive Islamic State militants told his intelligence agents of an alleged plot to attack subways in the United States and Paris.
item.media:text: NEW YORK (AP) — Iraq's prime minister said Thursday that captive Islamic State militants told his intelligence agents of an alleged plot to attack subways in the United States and Paris.

item.title: Iran's president says nuclear deal possible before deadline
item.description: UNITED NATIONS (AP) — Iran's president warned world leaders at the U.N. General Assembly on Thursday that the goal of extremists creating chaos in the Mideast is the destruction of civilization and rise of Islamophobia.
item.media:text: UNITED NATIONS (AP) — Iran's president warned world leaders at the U.N. General Assembly on Thursday that the goal of extremists creating chaos in the Mideast is the destruction of civilization and rise of Islamophobia.

item.media:text: Participation of Emirates' Maj. Mariam al-Mansouri, 35, stirred social media debate.

item.title: Key report in Michael Brown shooting doesn't exist, police say
item.description: Police in Ferguson, Mo., have violated their own standards since last month’s controversial fatal shooting of Michael Brown by Officer Darren Wilson.
item.media:text: Police in Ferguson, Mo., have violated their own standards since last month’s controversial fatal shooting of Michael Brown by Officer Darren Wilson.

item.title: ESPN suspends Bill Simmons for NFL, Goodell podcast rant
ESPN suspends Bill Simmons for Goodell, NFL rant
item.description: ESPN has suspended Bill Simmons for three weeks after he repeatedly called NFL Commissioner Roger Goodell a liar during a profane tirade on a podcast.
item.media:text: ESPN has suspended Bill Simmons for three weeks after he repeatedly called NFL Commissioner Roger Goodell a liar during a profane tirade on a podcast.

item.title: U.S. to pay Navajo tribe $554 million in landmark settlement
item.description: By Steve Gorman (Reuters) - The Obama administration has agreed to pay the Navajo Nation a record $554 million to settle longstanding claims by America's largest Indian tribe that its funds and natural resources were mishandled for decades by the U.S. government. The accord, resolving claims that date back as far as 50 years and marking the biggest U.S. legal settlement with a single tribe, will be formally signed at a ceremony on Friday in Window Rock, Arizona, the capital of the sprawling Navajo reservation. ...
item.media:text: By Steve Gorman (Reuters) - The Obama administration has agreed to pay the Navajo Nation a record $554 million to settle longstanding claims by America's largest Indian tribe that its funds and natural resources were mishandled for decades by the U.S. government. The accord, resolving claims that date back as far as 50 years and marking the biggest U.S. legal settlement with a single tribe, will be formally signed at a ceremony on Friday in Window Rock, Arizona, the capital of the sprawling Navajo reservation. ...

item.title: 14 reported dead in latest U.S.-led strikes
item.description: Overnight mission kills 14 militants in northeast Syria and 5 civilians, watchdog group says.
item.media:text: Overnight mission kills 14 militants in northeast Syria and 5 civilians, watchdog group says.

item.title: American describes life inside N. Korean prison
item.description: PYONGYANG, North Korea (AP) — An American man recently sentenced by North Korea to six years of hard labor says he is digging in fields eight hours a day and being kept in isolation, but that so far his health isn't deteriorating.
item.media:text: PYONGYANG, North Korea (AP) — An American man recently sentenced by North Korea to six years of hard labor says he is digging in fields eight hours a day and being kept in isolation, but that so far his health isn't deteriorating.

item.description: U.S.-led airstrikes target oil installations that have helped fund the militant group.
item.media:text: U.S.-led airstrikes target oil installations that have helped fund the militant group.

item.title: Tsarnaev trial delayed, but not moved

item.description: Bash is the software used to control the command prompt on many Linux computers.

item.title: Cops: Saw Pa. fugitive, found soiled diapers
item.description: Police find empty cigarette packs, soiled diapers believed to have been left by ambush suspect Eric Frein.
item.media:text: Police find empty cigarette packs, soiled diapers believed to have been left by ambush suspect Eric Frein.

item.title: U.S., allies launch new airstrikes in Syria
item.description: Pentagon: U.S., Arab aircraft have resumed bombing raids against IS jihadists in Syria.
item.media:text: Pentagon: U.S., Arab aircraft have resumed bombing raids against IS jihadists in Syria.

item.title: 2 victims identified in shooting at Ala. UPS facility
item.description: By Sherrel Wheeler Stewart BIRMINGHAM Ala. (Reuters) - Authorities on Wednesday released the names of the victims killed a day earlier in a murder-suicide at a UPS facility in Alabama, where police said an employee who had been fired shot dead two supervisors before turning the gun on himself. The victims in the Tuesday shooting in Birmingham were Doug Hutcheson, 33, and Brian Callans, 46, the Jefferson County Medical Examiner's Office said. ...
item.media:text: By Sherrel Wheeler Stewart BIRMINGHAM Ala. (Reuters) - Authorities on Wednesday released the names of the victims killed a day earlier in a murder-suicide at a UPS facility in Alabama, where police said an employee who had been fired shot dead two supervisors before turning the gun on himself. The victims in the Tuesday shooting in Birmingham were Doug Hutcheson, 33, and Brian Callans, 46, the Jefferson County Medical Examiner's Office said. ...

item.title: 13-year-old girl earns spot on middle school football team
item.description: Paige Smith made the Gladewater Middle School football team two years after coaches told her it would be impossible.

item.title: U.N. Security Council passes resolution on foreign jihadists
item.description: United Nations (United States) (AFP) - US President Barack Obama on Wednesday led the UN Security Council in approving a resolution demanding that countries take action to stem the flow of foreign jihadists to Iraq and Syria.
item.media:text: United Nations (United States) (AFP) - US President Barack Obama on Wednesday led the UN Security Council in approving a resolution demanding that countries take action to stem the flow of foreign jihadists to Iraq and Syria.

item.title: Clemson Univ. halts fraternity activities after student death
item.description: Clemson University has suspended activities for its 24 fraternities following the death of a student and recent reports of inappropriate behavior, school officials said.
item.media:text: Clemson University has suspended activities for its 24 fraternities following the death of a student and recent reports of inappropriate behavior, school officials said.

item.description: The victims said a group hurled gay slurs, beat them when the 2 parties passed on the street.

item.title: Dutch to send fighter jets to strike at IS in Iraq
item.description: The Dutch government says it will send six F-16 fighter jets to strike at the Islamic State extremist group in Iraq.
item.media:text: The Dutch government says it will send six F-16 fighter jets to strike at the Islamic State extremist group in Iraq.

item.title: Nigeria military claims Boko Haram leader dead
item.description: Nigeria's military on Wednesday claimed for the first time that Boko Haram leader Abubakar Shekau was dead, saying troops had shot a lookalike who had been posing as the militant commander.
